risk.question: What is my risk for developing lung cancer?
risk.answer: Your risk depends on several factors including smoking history, exposure to secondhand smoke, radon gas, asbestos, and family history. Smoking is the biggest risk factor.

risk.question: Based on my risk factors, when should I start lung cancer screening and how long should it be continued?
risk.answer: Screening is recommended for adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20 pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. It should be continued annually until the individual has not smoked for 15 years or develops a condition that limits life expectancy or the ability to have curative lung surgery.

risk.question: Does risk increase with age?
risk.answer: Yes, the risk of lung cancer increases with age, with most diagnoses occurring in people aged 65 and older.

risk.question: If I currently smoke, how do you suggest I quit and what resources are available for counseling?
risk.answer: To quit smoking, you can use a combination of counseling, nicotine replacement therapy (like patches or gum), and medications like varenicline or bupropion. Free resources include 1-800-QUIT-NOW and smokefree.gov.

risk.question: How can I reduce my risk of developing lung cancer?
risk.answer: Avoid smoking, minimize exposure to secondhand smoke and carcinogens like radon and asbestos, maintain a healthy diet, and exercise regularly.

insurance.question: Will my insurance pay for each lung cancer screening test you recommend?
insurance.answer: Most insurance plans, including Medicare, cover annual lung cancer screening with LDCT for eligible individuals without a copay, due to preventive care provisions under the Affordable Care Act.

insurance.question: Is there a copay for screening tests? How much?
insurance.answer: For most eligible individuals, there is no copay due to preventive service coverage, but this can vary by plan. It's best to check directly with your provider.

insurance.question: Do I have the insurance requirements to have lung cancer screening tests?
insurance.answer: Requirements typically include age range, smoking history, and a physician’s referral. Your provider can confirm eligibility.

insurance.question: Do I need an order before each screening test?
insurance.answer: Yes, a doctor’s order is usually required for lung cancer screening.

insurance.question: Do I need to see a specialist to prescribe the screening test?
insurance.answer: No, a primary care physician can order the screening if you meet the criteria.

insurance.question: Is this doctor or testing center in my network?
insurance.answer: You should confirm with your insurance provider to ensure the doctor and center are in-network to avoid unexpected costs.

screening.question: Should I be screened for lung cancer?
screening.answer: If you are aged 50–80, have a 20 pack-year smoking history, and currently smoke or quit within the last 15 years, you should be screened annually with LDCT.

screening.question: What screening plan do you recommend for me? Why?
screening.answer: Your screening plan depends on your risk profile. Annual LDCT scans are generally recommended for high-risk individuals to detect cancer early.

screening.question: What are the benefits and risks of this screening plan?
screening.answer: Benefits include early detection and better survival rates. Risks include false positives, radiation exposure, and potential anxiety or complications from follow-up procedures.

screening.question: Do you use LDCT for screening?
screening.answer: Yes, LDCT (Low-Dose Computed Tomography) is the preferred method for lung cancer screening.

screening.question: Where can I find a testing site?
screening.answer: You can ask your doctor or search for accredited screening centers on the American College of Radiology’s Lung Cancer Screening Registry.

screening.question: Do you have a team of experts who are dedicated to lung cancer screening?
screening.answer: Accredited centers typically have a team including radiologists, pulmonologists, and oncologists dedicated to lung cancer screening.

screening.question: Does the team of experts include a pulmonologist, thoracic surgeon, and thoracic radiologist?
screening.answer: Yes, comprehensive screening teams include these specialists for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

screening.question: What do I have to do to prepare for this screening test?
screening.answer: No special preparation is needed for LDCT, but you should follow your doctor’s instructions and wear loose, comfortable clothing.

screening.question: How long will this screening test take?
screening.answer: The LDCT scan itself takes only a few minutes, but the total visit may last about 30 minutes.

screening.question: How often will I have screening tests?
screening.answer: If you're eligible, you should have an LDCT scan annually.

test_results.question: When will I know the test results and who will explain them to me?
test_results.answer: Results are usually available within a few days. Your doctor or a lung specialist will explain them to you.

test_results.question: How can I get a copy of the pathology report and other test results?
test_results.answer: You can request a copy through your patient portal or medical records department at the healthcare facility.

test_results.question: What type of nodule(s) do I have? What does this mean?
test_results.answer: Lung nodules can be benign or malignant. Their size, shape, and growth rate help determine the risk. Your doctor will explain the findings.

test_results.question: Do I need more tests?
test_results.answer: If a suspicious nodule is found, your doctor may recommend follow-up imaging or a biopsy.

test_results.question: How long until my next test?
test_results.answer: This depends on your results. If normal, another test is due in one year; otherwise, your doctor will advise a follow-up schedule.

biopsies.question: Do I need a biopsy? What type of biopsy will I have?
biopsies.answer: If imaging shows a suspicious area, a biopsy may be needed. Types include needle biopsy, bronchoscopy, or surgical biopsy.

biopsies.question: What are the risks with this type of biopsy?
biopsies.answer: Risks include bleeding, infection, and lung collapse (pneumothorax), but complications are relatively rare.

biopsies.question: Who will perform the biopsy?
biopsies.answer: A pulmonologist, interventional radiologist, or thoracic surgeon typically performs the procedure.

biopsies.question: What will you do to make me comfortable during the biopsy?
biopsies.answer: Local anesthesia and sometimes sedation are used to ensure comfort. You may also receive post-procedure pain management.

biopsies.question: When and where will the biopsy be done?
biopsies.answer: It is usually scheduled at a hospital or outpatient center depending on the type. Your care team will provide details.

biopsies.question: How many of these types of biopsies are done at this hospital every year?
biopsies.answer: You can ask the hospital directly. High-volume centers typically have more experience and better outcomes.

biopsies.question: How will my biopsy be performed?
biopsies.answer: Depending on the method, it may involve a needle guided by CT scan, a bronchoscopy, or minor surgery.

biopsies.question: What else might be done during the biopsy?
biopsies.answer: Additional samples may be taken for genetic or molecular testing if cancer is suspected.

biopsies.question: How will I feel after the biopsy?
biopsies.answer: You may feel mild pain or discomfort. Most people recover within a day or two, but follow post-procedure advice.

biopsies.question: How do I find out the biopsy results and who will discuss them with me?
biopsies.answer: Your doctor or specialist will contact you to explain the results, typically within a few days.
